Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: 3-Dimensional Data Output from Remote Sensing Algorithms
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to develop a 3-dimensional view of agricultural fields using algorithms applied to remotely sensed imagery to help farmers enhance soil fertility and crop production while also protecting watersheds. From an economic perspective, farmers want to minimize expenditures on nutrients. There is a need by farmers to increase below ground drainage through installation of tiles, perforated plastic pipes, and thus increase production. Tile placement and integrity, coupled with existing data on soil type and characteristics, have a critical impact on the hydrology and fertility of fields, affecting plant growth, the need for fertilizer/nutrients, pesticide and other types of applications. Precise knowledge of a three dimensional view of the land will enable farmers to make appropriate decisions about the application of fertilizers, micro-nutrients, pesticides, etc. to minimize cost, maximize revenue and do as little harm as possible to the ecosystem in which the farm exists. Bringing together data layers of agricultural fields along with information on tile drains will allow the agricultural industry to optimize production through proper placement and repair of tiles while controlling nutrient use and loss.

This I-Corps project uses remote sensing techniques with aerial imagery to provide information precisely identifying the location of drain tiles buried beneath farm fields. Farmers have expressed that knowledge of the location of tile reduces their costs when tile fail and need repair and also helps when additional tile are added to a field improving drainage. In previous work, it was found that fertilizers applied to agricultural fields will pass through the soil and exit a field through tile drains to the surface water system. This I-Corps project uses remote sensing algorithms to detect tile drains below the soil. The technique utilizes the reflectance of the soil as well as the linear shape expressed on the soil surface that indicates tiles within fields. The information generated through this project is unique and much needed by the agricultural industry to better utilize land in crop production "precision farming".

POR.DRECONTENT:
Goals

The primary goal of this project was to test the potential to commercialize a product developed using GIS (geospatial information systems) and remote sensing technologies to identify subsurface agricultural tile drainage systems. We developed an automated algorithm to detect subsurface drainage systems in agricultural fields. A secondary goal was to educate the team on entrepreneurial concepts and approaches so that the team could determine the viability of our product and whether we should start a company, i.e. would it make money?

We developed algorithms using remote sensing imagery to detect tile drains below the soil. Our technique is unique in that we map the tiles using object-oriented classification. The technique utilizes the spectral reflectance of the imagery as well as the geometrical shape expressed on the soil surface that indicates tiles within fields.

Intellectual Merit

We brought together a team of a professor, Kevin Czajkowski, graduate student, Kimberly Panozzo, and entrepreneur, Navin Singhania, to participate in the 6-week, I-Corps Bay Area cohort in Oakland, California in the summer of 2017. Through the program, the team attended training in Oakland, spent the summer of 2017 conducting potential customer interviews and then presented our final outcome near the end of the summer. We developed a business plan including how much customers would be willing to pay for our product and what that product should be.

Through over 120 interviews, we found many potential customer segments (CS) and some that may be significantly more lucrative then others. The team came to the program with the proposal that tile drain detection would be useful in environmental protection. However, the team found that pursuing a company focused on environmental protection would not be economically fruitful. Then, the team thought that tile drain installers would benefit from knowing where tiles are in fields for installing more tile or fixing tile. We found that was true, however, we also found that our ability to locate tiles below ground may not be accurate enough for tile installers so it may not be something they would pay for. In our process of identifying the CS for a minimum viable product (MVP), we interviewed many potential customer segments prior to our pivot to auctioneers. Our ?Ah-Ha? moment happened during a review of insights gathered from farmers, suggesting real estate (or notably-auctioneers) sold agricultural land for a higher price if maps of subsurface drainage systems were available. At the end of the six weeks, our team decided that we were a ?no go? for forming a company. Our graduate student was just about to start the Spatially Integrated Social Sciences PhD program at the University of Toledo and it was not a good time to start a company. At the end of this project, we are still a ?no go?, however we are closer to being able to start a company than at the end of 2017.

Broader Impacts

Although a company was not formed through this project, there were broader impacts from the project.  One of the outcomes of the project was the conclusion that our algorithm may not be accurate enough for tile drain installers to use to save them time and money. Throughout the 2018-19 academic year, Ms. Panozzo has refined the algorithm for pinpointing tile drains so that it is more accurate. She has also increased the efficiency for identifying tile lines so that large areas, on the order of several counties, can be processed quickly at one time. Through the program, Ms. Panozzo also learned how to present more effectively and to be more confident in her abilities. This has influenced the other eight PhD students who work in the research lab with her thus improving the overall abilities of the group.

This project has also changed how the team looks at research at the university. One of the broader impacts is that this project changed the way the PI approaches research projects, looking at the needs of participants and collaborators as well as stakeholders. This contributed to the PI receiving a grant with Co-I Dr. Rai from the Ohio Department of Higher Education called Effectiveness In Implementation: Mapping Agricultural Management Practices, Farmer Perceptions And Outcomes for $120,889.
